ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: understanding of the theoretical and conceptual debate on terrorism. Appreciation for the academic and journalistic literature on the phenomena.
Learned so much about terrorism. Academic/theoretical definitions, case studies throughout history, and factors that cause/don't cause people to radicalize and become terrorists.
This class totally reframed my outlook on terrorism and what we consider "terrorist" in the United States.
I learned a lot about what terrorism is and how to critically question the news

I learned how to develop and apply definitions of phenomenons to real world puzzles. I also learned why it is often challenging to pin something like terrorism down with one definition. Finally, I learned how to categorize groups and individuals based on the definition I had developed since the advent of the class.

This course was a great introduction to terrorism, the difficulties of categorizing political violence, and the methodology used to analyse both. I learned about how data can be used to label different actions, how peace negotiations are conducted, and who has a stake in counterterrorism negotiations.

The seminar "Terrorism" taught me about how and why terrorism occurs in a variety of contexts across the globe. The seminar's guest speakers helped me to understand why people become terrorists or join terrorist organizations. The seminar had a particular focus on the Troubles in Northern Ireland, and sparked my interest in learning more about this conflict.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: extremely original framework for learning where we skype in with ex-terrorists, counter-terrorists, academics, and peace-negotiators. very good readings with excellent topics for conversation. Course builds in a sensible way.

weaknesses: more opportunity in class to debrief about the people with whom we spoke.

Strengths: All of the guest speakers really work to expand students' understanding of the theoretical concepts in a way that reading journal articles and books simply cannot. Also, Professor Weir is an absolutely incredible professor the way she engages with students and really challenges them to bring unique ideas to class is incredibly valuable. Weaknesses: I would have personally preferred more assignments to engage with the core concepts of the course.

Strengths: Absolutely amazing readings and discussions. Completely driven by the students and Professor Weir is so so knowledgeable about the subject. Having guest speakers was absolutely amazing to hear from their perspective about the issues we were reading and discussing. Strengths are basically every aspect of the course (besides the one weakness below). Literally no complaints

Weakness: Super personal, but would have appreciated discussing Northern Ireland less. It's Professor Weir's topic of study and she has a lot of contacts so it makes sense, but early on in the semester, we concluded that many groups in Northern Ireland didn't qualify as terrorist organizations. This was mentioned in the syllabus though, so not even really a complaint.
I loved the speakers! I think there could definitely be more feedback from the professor on our assignments.

Strengths - I loved the guest speakers and the topics
Weakness - A bit disorganized sometimes

The strengths of this course included the speakers and the thematic presentations. I found them to be really helpful in firming up certain concepts.
One weakness is that I felt we spent too much time engaging in discussions that it either cut into upcoming discussions or shortened the thematic presentations. A stricter control on time allocation might be helpful.
I truly enjoyed this course but I believe it could be improved by giving students an opportunity to write a final essay on a topic of their choosing.

The seminar "Terrorism" was extremely well-designed to facilitate student learning and engagement. The readings were interesting and relevant, the guest speakers were amazing, and student discussion was aided by both Professor Weir's insights and the insights of students from a variety of unique backgrounds. 

One suggestion would be to allot a certain amount of time to each meeting's thematic presentation. Some of the presentations were shortened as a result of guest speakers and other presentations running behind, detracting from discussion.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: successes: skyping with people across the world, presentations by students

This course was perfect for online (@Yale don't take that to mean I want you to keep online courses). Our guest speakers were from all over the world, so having them Zoom into class was very effective. Like any course though, discussion just isn't the same when it is done over Zoom; there's those awkward pauses and people mute and unmute themselves. Nothing to improve upon on the professor's part, we just need to get back to in-person learning.
I thought this class was basically perfect in terms of zoom adjustment. I have no complaints here.

The seminar effectively used guest speakers and student-led thematic presentations to guide our online discussions. One suggestion would be to incorporate more media on terrorism to further bolster learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. It is a very unique learning environment and professor weir has some amazing connections. There is no other course like this at Yale and it is a really special opportunity and way to learn.
100 percent! I really do not think there are many other courses at Yale that engage the class in the same way as Professor Weir's course on Terrorism. I cannot recommend it enough.

YES! I am not a PLSC major but the course was absolutely fascinating. Professor Weir is amazing and the material is just so interesting. There also isn't much work, but you still learn so much information. Would recommend to absolutely anyone with some interest in terrorism.
Definitely! Super interesting and workload was very manageable. Also really relevant right now.
I would highly recommend it. It's very interesting!
Sure! The content is interesting and the speakers will keep you on your toes.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Professor Weir brought in so many amazing speakers who really helped me understand terrorism from those who had experienced it first-hand. It was such a unique opportunity.
I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in learning about terrorism and willing to dedicate themselves to in-depth discussion on the topic.

comments: N/A
